page.title: 02PAINSWICK BEACON
page.content: Painswick Beacon is an area of rough grassland, situated one and a quarter miles north of the village, and lying 929 feet above sea level. The Beacon was the site of Kimsbury Iron Age hill-fort and was defended by a set of ditches on the south, east and west sides, forming a triangle, and covering seven acres.The original site has been damaged by a golf course and some old disused quarries. The golf course has eighteen holes,with both course and clubhouse running next to a wood.The old quarries are mainly slate.There is a stone on the top of the Beacon which is a triangulation or mapping point. In 1977, the Beacon was used to light a Jubilee Beacon, to celebrate the Silver Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II.Today it is mainly a recreational area, where people go to play golf, or
